publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

msIdentifier.repository: Bibliothèque nationale de France, fonds Pelliot Koutchéen (Paris)

seg.seg: Thereupon the brahmin after having set up a house of reeds on the earth for us two little boys close to his hut, before these prince(s) ...

...he expelled us, the princes, from (?) the forest, while desiring (us) [and while] we were crying (lit. making shout) because of the suffering. In that way after having seen the two miserable prince younglings ...
... they somehow develop ... for him. Having definitely become feeble because of the suffering he sat down to earth at the door of the hermitage. Then he says, in (the tune) haridāsañe: ...
... by very ... in the world. Precisely this suffering of the separation surpasses all sufferings. Through endurance the blissful ones ... me (from?) dust-thinking ...
... the fire burns this (scil. heart) of me sharply. From the sky one says (lit. they say), in (the tune) haṃsavaṅk: If it will be possible for us ... each divine world utterly ...
... to ... or to flay the skin from the body for the sake of him, not at all ... the homage to the loving (made?) to/by you ...
... the powerful suffering ... with the sympathetic woman ...
... they compare ... . The big yakṣas ... by joy ... they were ... the gods belonging to ... again ...
... may they obtain they quality because of joyful love. Here all say, in (the tune) taruṇadivākar: O bull, having produced such big thing now ...
... you have abandoned the two little boys without selfishness, o lord. You have created for yourself fully the second perfection, this pure cauldron consisting of a/the gift.

... in order to leave ... But if the wish will become true for you, if you reach the place of the omniscient the world would shine. The color of the Law characterized by the truths without negligence ...
... but may you remind us in that time, [us] who have been lead astray by the passions as it were. May you give us the riches consisting of eternity for sure, o lord! 2 (In the guise of) princes
... [now] the gods are seen. The nāgas have been joyful [saying]: I [am] bound to taking care of, [my] birth [is] for omniscience, hundred (scil. riches) does not count for me anymore ...
... It is time for us now to go down to the forest. Let us bring the princes. In (the tune) nandavilāpa: O you, bender of the Sumeru mountain as it were ...

p.note: For na the sign ma is written, i.e. the text has been copied from a manuscript in archaic ductus.
At the end of the line is the beginning of a metrical passage. The name of the meter is haridāsañe. This meter consists of 4x14 syllables with a rhythm 7/7.
This fragment is the right part of a leaf including traces of the string hole which interrupts lines 3, 4, and 5.

The m-participle kawänamane probably belongs to the root kāw- 'to desire' from a present class VI which is not attested so far, but which should be expected as patterning with subjunctive V and preterite I. The present class XII attested for this root would be a secondary formation.

The form etkeṃ can be interpreted as an adverb base on the compound en-tkeṃ with regular loss of the nasal as in other similar prefixed formations. This contains the archaic form keṃ 'earth' which would also be attested in line b1.

The reading 〈ykāka〉 allows to connect the adverb that means 'surely' which is base on yaka. The alternative reading 〈ykeka〉 would force to assume a form of the noun īke 'place' which can not be constructed in this context.
The first akṣara of the word curṇ is written with double marking of the vowel 〈u〉, possibly by self correction of the scribe.

In the middle of the line is the beginning of a metrical passage. The name of the meter is haṃsavaṅk. It also occurs in Tocharian A, cf. b2. It seems to follow the pattern 4x13 syllables with a rhythm of 7/6 plus a pāda with 21 syllables with a rhythm of 8/8/5.
The remnants on the manuscript allow the reading 〈(r)mare〉 which would be the 3. pl. active preterite of the root räm- 'to compare'.
It is very likely that the taru is the beginning of the meter name taruṇadivākar. This meter consists of 19|19|10|19 syllables with the rhythm 7/7/5 in pāda a, b, d, and 5/5 in pāda c.

The first colon of the pāda 2d has one syllable too much. It is possible that the particle ra has been wrongly added by a later copyist since it does not contribute significantly to the meaning. An alternative proposal would be an allegro pronunciation of the genitive plural of kleśa with syncope of the middle syllable.
The form ñmäntai belongs to the root näm- 'bend, bow' and is an agent noun of the type seen in yokänta 'drinker'.
At the end of the line is the beginning of a metrical passage. The name of the meter is nandavilāp. This meter consists of 4x15 syllables with a rhythm 7/8.

list.item: This fragment is the right part of a leaf including traces of the string hole which interrupts lines 3, 4, and 5.

nemc= ekñi ñäktā 2 #2d || mcu(ṣkäññe weṣsa) /// b6 /// – lyelyäkoṣ ñäkti • nāgi tesa kakāccoṣ yä(rpa)ll(e)ṣṣe ñäśo poyśiññe c(m)el mā ṣpä kante|känte stärñ ś – ·k· ne /// b7 /// – preke wesäñ ñäke ente wärttone kārpatsi • (kāl)l(am) pi mñcuṣkeṃ|mc(u)ṣkeṃ || nandavilāpne|nandavilāpn(e) || # ñmäntai ramt sume(r-ṣ)le /// #1a

a1 Thereupon the brahmin after having set up a house of reeds on the earth for us two little boys close to his hut, before these prince(s) ... a2 ...he expelled us, the princes, from (?) the forest, while desiring (us) [and while] we were crying (lit. making shout) because of the suffering. In that way after having seen the two miserable prince younglings ... a3 ... they somehow develop ... for him. Having definitely become feeble because of the suffering he sat down to earth at the door of the hermitage. Then he says, in (the tune) haridāsañe: ... a4 ... by very ... in the world. Precisely this suffering of the separation surpasses all sufferings. Through endurance the blissful ones ... me (from?) dust-thinking ... a5 ... the fire burns this (scil. heart) of me sharply. From the sky one says (lit. they say), in (the tune) haṃsavaṅk: If it will be possible for us ... each divine world utterly ... a6 ... to ... or to flay the skin from the body for the sake of him, not at all ... the homage to the loving (made?) to/by you ... a7 ... the powerful suffering ... with the sympathetic woman ... b1 ... they compare ... . The big yakṣas ... by joy ... they were ... the gods belonging to ... again ... b2 ... may they obtain they quality because of joyful love. Here all say, in (the tune) taruṇadivākar: O bull, having produced such big thing now ... b3 ... you have abandoned the two little boys without selfishness, o lord. You have created for yourself fully the second perfection, this pure cauldron consisting of a/the gift. b4 ... in order to leave ... But if the wish will become true for you, if you reach the place of the omniscient the world would shine. The color of the Law characterized by the truths without negligence ... b5 ... but may you remind us in that time, [us] who have been lead astray by the passions as it were. May you give us the riches consisting of eternity for sure, o lord! 2 (In the guise of) princes b6 ... [now] the gods are seen. The nāgas have been joyful [saying]: I [am] bound to taking care of, [my] birth [is] for omniscience, hundred (scil. riches) does not count for me anymore ... b7 ... It is time for us now to go down to the forest. Let us bring the princes. In (the tune) nandavilāpa: O you, bender of the Sumeru mountain as it were ...
Bibliothèque nationale de France, fonds Pelliot Koutchéen (Paris)

a2. The m-participle kawänamane probably belongs to the root kāw- 'to desire' from a present class VI which is not attested so far, but which should be expected as patterning with subjunctive V and preterite I. The present class XII attested for this root would be a secondary formation.
a3. The form etkeṃ can be interpreted as an adverb base on the compound en-tkeṃ with regular loss of the nasal as in other similar prefixed formations. This contains the archaic form keṃ 'earth' which would also be attested in line b1.

b7. The form ñmäntai belongs to the root näm- 'bend, bow' and is an agent noun of the type seen in yokänta 'drinker'.

a1 /// t·e • || tum[e](·) br·hm·ṇe _k_a·w[ā]ṣṣ[e] o_s_t(·) tk[e]··sa śa_m_a (– –) _s_añ [sp·] k·ṣk·ne śeśc·[n··m·] e[n]·pr· – mcuṣke – – /// a2 /// [_l_a]klesa wek ya_m_askemane mcuṣkeṃ kawänamane wärt(·)o[m]·· lyuttsate-me • taiknesa tall[ā]ñco mcuṣke-saiwiśka[n](e) lye[l··] /// a3 /// ○ ra plet_k_ar-ne • _l_akleñ ylāre kaklautkau yk[ā]ka aśra_m_antse twerene etkeṃ [lya]ma : [_t_a]ne we_ṣ_ṣ_a[ṃ] || hari[dā]sa·e /// a4 /// ○ rs= olypo śaiṣṣene : sek ra _l_akle tsrelleṣṣe po _l_aklenta _ṣ_ar_k_ast_r_a : _k_a_l_ṣ_amñesa [s]ākreñ ñäś\ [c]ur_ṇ\ _p_al[sk]o /// a5 /// ○ puwar mātre t_s_a_k_ṣ_añ tā [1] || akāśmeṃ weskeṃ || haṃsavaṅne || kr_ui yātoy we_s_añä\ ārtsa śaiṣṣe pes[t]\ ñäk(c)i – /// a6 /// katsi yetse kektseñ[m]eṃ t_s_aṅtsi epe no _t_añ pelkiñä\ mā ṅke _ṣ_a (– – –) – _t_aṅwälñentse yärke _t_añ (·)e /// a7 /// [y]yacce _l_akle [k]e – ṣ·ā l·· me[ṃ] – (– – – ) ·i – na – (– – – – –) [y·] ś[l]e [ā]ñmalaṣk[ai] k[l]aiṃ – /// b1 /// ·mä ·mare • wrocc· (–) [yak]ṣi ka[tkew]ñ[ai] (– – – –) – (–) [n]t_r_a – (– – – – –) – wcäṣṣi ñäkti na[no] – /// b2 /// – ññe kakācco_ṣ\ _t_aṅw[s]ā [_k_ä]l[l]on_t_ar-ne • [_t_a]ne poñc weskeṃ || taru[ṇ·] – (– – –) [ṣu] ttot wrocce wäntre ceṃ ñk= erw· [k·] /// b3 /// ○_l_aṃṣki saiwiśkane rintsātai snai eṅ_k_al ñäktā : kyānat(·) [s·]lm(·) parāmit wäce ayorṣṣe ceṃ a[s]tr= [ai] – – /// b4 /// ○ _l_antsi [1] kr_ui no kñī_t_ar-cc ākālko yänmoy[t] īke poyśiññe lyuśi[_t_a]r śaiṣṣe pelaikneṣṣe yo_k\ snai ar[tt]= e[mpr]e /// b5 /// ○w preke wes no epyac _k_aloytā_r\ oś kakāma_ṣ\ kle_ś_anmant_s\ ra k[c]= āy[i]t-me onwāññeṣṣe nemc= e[kñi] ñäktā 2 || m[c]u- /// b6 /// – lyelyäkoṣ ñäkti • nāgi tesa kakācco_ṣ\ yä – ll(·) ṣṣe ñäśo [p]oyśiññe c·e[l]\[•] mā _ṣ_p_a [_k_a]nte s_t_arñä\ ś – ·[k]· ne /// b7 /// – [pr]eke we_s_añä\ ñä[k]e [e]nte wärttone kār[p]atsi [•] (–) l(·) pi m[c](u)ṣkeṃ || nandavilā[pn·] || ñ[m_a]_ntai ram_t_a(·) sume··[l]e ///
Georges-Jean Pinault (in collaboration with Melanie Malzahn, Hannes A. Fellner)

For na the sign ma is written, i.e. the text has been copied from a manuscript in archaic ductus.


a4. The first akṣara of the word curṇ is written with double marking of the vowel 〈u〉, possibly by self correction of the scribe.

a3. The reading 〈ykāka〉 allows to connect the adverb that means 'surely' which is base on yaka. The alternative reading 〈ykeka〉 would force to assume a form of the noun īke 'place' which can not be constructed in this context.

At the end of the line is the beginning of a metrical passage. The name of the meter is haridāsañe. This meter consists of 4x14 syllables with a rhythm 7/7.

a5. In the middle of the line is the beginning of a metrical passage. The name of the meter is haṃsavaṅk. It also occurs in Tocharian A, cf. [[A 299]] b2. It seems to follow the pattern 4x13 syllables with a rhythm of 7/6 plus a pāda with 21 syllables with a rhythm of 8/8/5.

b1. The remnants on the manuscript allow the reading 〈(r)mare〉 which would be the 3. pl. active preterite of the root räm- 'to compare'.

b2. It is very likely that the taru is the beginning of the meter name taruṇadivākar. This meter consists of 19|19|10|19 syllables with the rhythm 7/7/5 in pāda a, b, d, and 5/5 in pāda c.
b5 The first colon of the pāda 2d has one syllable too much. It is possible that the particle ra has been wrongly added by a later copyist since it does not contribute significantly to the meaning. An alternative proposal would be an allegro pronunciation of the genitive plural of kleśa with syncope of the middle syllable.

b7. At the end of the line is the beginning of a metrical passage. The name of the meter is nandavilāp. This meter consists of 4x15 syllables with a rhythm 7/8.
